results.title: reLOCATED - Mr and Mrs Kemp
results.brief_description: Kensington - this short film is created from a series of photographs and interviews with Mr and Mrs Kemp, residents of the Kensington Public Housing estate for 38 years. ‘reLOCATED’ documents the lives of residents from the estate who were moved when the estate was redeveloped. It is a visual record of how places contain the memories of people’s lives as well as a fantastic example of how you can use non-video media to make a powerful moving image story.

results.title: Supervising women workers
results.creator_credit: Herbert Kerkow and United States. Office of Education
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Problems in Supervision”.
A factory foreman discusses with the supervisor the “problem” of supervising women workers in his department. The fact is brought out that the same rules apply in supervising both men and women; but, “as women often have not had as much industrial experience as men, and in most cases have more home responsibilities than men, these factors must be taken into account”. Note that this film was made in 1944 and uses such terms as “breaking in” the female workers and “the eternal feminine”. Interesting from a historical point of view.

results.title: Begone dull care
results.creator_credit: Norman McLaren, Evelyn Lambart and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A lively interpretation of jazz music played by the Oscar Peterson Trio. The music is visually represented in a series of abstract lines and shapes, hand painted directly on to the film, culminating in a fast and furious explosion as the tempo quickens. One of the high points of jazz in cinema (and of McLaren’s career).

results.title: 70 years at Brunswick Baths
results.brief_description: Brunswick - Harry Ivory, a fitness fanatic, a boxer, boxing trainer and local legend has been attending the Brunswick Baths since the day it opened in 1928. Part of a longer documentary about Harry’s life, this 4 minute film was made especially for the MAP project and focuses on the importance to him of the Brunswick Baths and the Baths community. Harry loves the place and often says it is the Baths that keep him going.

results.title: People (Yallourn's Royal Hour 1954; Born to Die; Sir John Monash)

video_links.name: People (Yallourn's Royal Hour 1954; Born to Die; Sir John Monash)

results.brief_description: “Yallourn’s Royal Hour” highlights the visit to Yallourn of Queen Elizabeth II and the Duke of Edinburgh on 3rd March 1954. Film of the royal motorcade through Melbourne is shown before their arrival in Yallourn where they inspect the coal extraction site at Yallourn Cut (16 min). “Born to Die” focuses on the prospect that Yallourn will be demolished to enable access to the coal reserves beneath it. Includes comments by the townspeople on their feelings about this. (48 mins) “Sir John Monash” is a tribute to the life of this pioneer Australian. The Vice Chancellor of Monash University speaks on his life and an account of his achievements is given. (27 min)
results.title_for_label: People (Yallourn’s Royal Hour 1954; Born to Die; Sir John Monash)

results.title: Made in Hong Kong = Xianggang zhizao [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Nicetop Independent, Team Work Production House, Andrew Lau, Doris Yang and Fruit Chan
results.brief_description: This low budget teen flick, the first independent film to emerge from the former British colony, certainly captured the critics’ praise and received several international awards for its young Chinese director, Fruit Chan. The central character, Autumn Moon (Sam Lee), who, abandoned by his father and living with his mother in the back streets of urban Hong Kong where crime, gangs and violence exist on a daily basis, operates as a small-time debt collector for Wing, his triad “big brother”. Moon is a survivor and although he acts cool and mean, can also show compassion and tenderness, particularly for the under-dog as in the case of Sylvester (Wenbers Li), a mentally handicapped friend whom he zealously protects from bullying gangs and Ping (Neiky Yim), the daughter of one of his debtors, who is suffering from a fatal kidney disease and who Moon soon finds himself falling for. A young schoolgirl’s suicide will inextricably link the lives of Moon, Sylvester and Ping taking them down a sad and tragic path of despair and violence but one begins to empathise with Moon along this journey as he tries to protect those he loves. Gritty, tender, violent, comic, “Made in Hong Kong” is film noir in style with Moon acting as narrator throughout the story but it is also expressionistic visually, using strobe, overexposure, freeze-frames, and jump-cutting, adding depth and enhancement to Chan’s debut film. Cast also includes Amy Tam, Carol Lam, Doris Chow, Wu Wai-chung. In Mandarin with English subtitles. (Awards: Locarno; Gijon; Hong Kong)

results.title: Picnic at Hanging Rock (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Peter Weir, Patricia Lovell, Jim McElroy, Hal McElroy and McElroy & McElroy
results.brief_description: In the summer of 1900 three girls from a private school and their teacher unaccountably vanish on a St Valentine’s Day school picnic to a mysterious rock in the midst of the Australian bush. The Victorian girls’ school for the daughters of the privileged gradually becomes contaminated and destroyed from within by its inability to understand the forces confronting it. Based on a novel which mythologises the emergence of sexuality, the film atmospherically follows various tangents without distilling a sense of explanation. Unease is evoked by the horror of not knowing. Based on the novel by Joan Lindsay. Cast includes Rachel Roberts, Dominic Guard, Helen Morse and Jacki Weaver.

results.title: Late Winter to Early Spring
results.brief_description: The threads of several simple stories - a young boy encounters an old man down on his luck, two couples meet - are wordlessly interwoven to evoke the rhythm of life in a public park (Fitzroy Gardens, Melbourne) in the passing age of winter and the youthful beauty of the approaching spring. Brealey acknowledged the influence of Arne Sucksdorff (Rhythm of a city) on his approach to this film. In ‘Sunday in Melbourne’ (1958) he took a different approach eschewing staged narrative.

results.title: Learning Through Play
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Alexander, Don Hauser, World Organisation for early Childhood Development and Monash University
results.brief_description: Looks at play amongst three year-olds and the more highly developed and realistic play of five year-olds. Shows the role of the teacher in various situations providing challenging equipment to extend the interests of the children and in guiding play to complement structured learning.
